qas.question: What eponymous variation of arithmetic presents a decision problem not evidenced in P?
Despite the Presburger problem, and in view of intractability, what has been done to establish solutions in reasonable periods of time?

answers.text: algorithms have been written that solve the problem in reasonable times in most cases

qas.question: What is an example of a problem to which effective algorithms have provided a solution in spite of the intractability associated with the breadth of sizes?
How quickly can an algorithm solve an NP-complete knapsack problem?
What is the example of another problem characterized by large instances that is routinely solved by SAT handlers employing efficient algorithms?
What unknown variation of arithmetic presents a decision problem not evidenced in P?
What has not been done to establish solutions in reasonable period of time?
What can not solve the NP-complete knapsack problem over a wide range of sizes in less than quadratic time?

plausible_answers.text: SAT solvers routinely handle large instances of the NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem.

qas.question: What do SAT solvers not usually handle when testing?

context: What intractability means in practice is open to debate. Saying that a problem is not in P does not imply that all large cases of the problem are hard or even that most of them are. For example, the decision problem in <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>Presburger<a0_1/> arithmetic<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_0/> has been shown not to be in P, yet <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>algorithms<b6_0/> have been written<a1_1/><a1_0/> that solve the problem in reasonable times in most cases<a1_2/>. Similarly, <b7_0>algorithms<b7_0/> can solve <a2_2>the <a2_0><a2_1>NP-complete knapsack<a2_1/> problem<a2_2/><a2_0/> over a wide range of sizes <a3_0>in <a3_1><a3_2>less than quadratic time<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> and <b8_0>SAT solvers routinely handle large instances of <a4_2>the <a4_0><a4_1>NP-complete Boolean satisfiability<a4_1/> problem<a4_2/><a4_0/>.
